DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Fiscal 1990 Draft Budget
DOC.TEXT: The government Sunday approved a draft $466.7 billion budget for fiscal 1990 that for the first time in 15 years does not rely on deficit-financing bonds. The Cabinet held a special meeting to accept the Finance Ministry's draft budget for the fiscal year beginning in March. The budget represents a 9.7 percent increase over current spending. It calls for increases of 5.5 percent in defense spending, to $29.1 billion; 5.9 percent in aid to developing countries, to about $5.6 billion; and 6.2 percent in social security spending, to $81.5 billion. The increases reflect growing tax revenues flowing from Japan's booming economy, which just entered its fourth year of continuous expansion. Further negotiations will fine-tune specific allocations for the final version of the budget, which is expected to be approved Friday. The Cabinet also approved a supplementary budget for the current fiscal year. The $41.5 billion budget is the largest stop-gap budget ever. ``The greatest thrust of this year's budget is the desire of the government to end its dependence on deficit-financing bonds,'' a Foreign Ministry official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Since they were first introduced in 1975, we have made earnest efforts to end this dependency. We were finally able to rid ourselves of this unhealthy system.'' The government issued $9.3 billion worth of deficit-financing bonds last year to cover the budget's red ink. That amount will be made up in part by an infusion in fiscal 1990 of $9.15 billion from government sales last year of its shares in Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp., as well as increased tax revenues, the official said. Defense spending will rise to $29.1 billion, but because of economic expansion, the defense budget will dip below 1 percent of Japan's gross national product for the first time in four years, standing at 0.991 percent of the GNP. In the mid-1970s Japan adopted a policy of keeping defense spending to within 1 percent of the GNP, but since 1986 it has hovered just above that figure. Spending on public works will rise 0.3 percent to $43.8 billion next fiscal year. Although the United States has urged Japan to increase such publicly funded projects to help ease Tokyo's trade surplus with Washington, the marginal increase ``is sufficient,'' the Finance Ministry official said. The draft budget was compiled on the basis of government estimates that the economy will grow an inflation-adjusted 4 percent next year, a brisk pace despite a slowdown from the estimated 4.6 percent growth in fiscal 1989. An unusual addition to the fiscal 1990 budget was $39 million for the formal enthronement ceremonies of Emperor Akihito, and $958,000 for the wedding of Akihito's second son, Prince Aya.
